outputValidation.content:
{
  "problem_id": "P02",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 1.85,
    "units": "g",
    "precision_note": "Inputs (5.00 g, 84.0%) are 3 s.f.; final mass reported to 3 s.f."
  },
  "method": "First find the mass of pure CaCO3 in the limestone: m(CaCO3) = 5.00 g × 0.840 = 4.20 g. Calculate Mr(CaCO3) from the given atomic masses: CaCO3 has Ca (40.1) + C (12.0) + 3×O (3×16.0) = 100.1. Moles of CaCO3: n = m/Mr = 4.20/100.1 = 0.04196 mol. From the equation CaCO3 + 2HCl → CaCl2 + CO2 + H2O, the mole ratio CaCO3:CO2 is 1:1, so n(CO2) = 0.04196 mol. Mr(CO2) from atomic masses is C (12.0) + 2×O (2×16.0) = 44.0, so mass of CO2 = n×Mr = 0.04196 × 44.0 = 1.85 g (3 s.f.).",
  "key_equations": [
    "n = m / Mr",
    "m(pure) = m(sample) × purity",
    "From CaCO3 → CO2, n(CO2) = n(CaCO3)",
    "m = n × Mr"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L14",
    "L24",
    "L33",
    "L34"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "If the sample were 100% CaCO3, CO2 mass would be 5.00×(44.0/100.1) ≈ 2.20 g; 84% purity gives ≈ 1.85 g, which is consistent.",
    "Stoichiometry is 1 mol CaCO3 producing 1 mol CO2 per the balanced equation."
  ]
}

{
  "problem_id": "P05",
  "final_answer": {
    "value": 0.889,
    "units": "g",
    "precision_note": "Current (1.50 A) and time (30.0 min) are 3 s.f.; mass reported to 3 s.f."
  },
  "method": "Convert time to seconds: 30.0 min = 30.0×60 = 1800 s. Charge passed: Q = I×t = 1.50×1800 = 2700 C. Moles of electrons transferred: n(e−) = Q/F = 2700/96500 = 0.02798 mol. From Cu2+ + 2e− → Cu, 2 mol e− deposit 1 mol Cu, so n(Cu) = 0.02798/2 = 0.01399 mol. Using Ar(Cu) = 63.55, mass deposited m = n×Ar = 0.01399×63.55 = 0.889 g.",
  "key_equations": [
    "Q = I × t",
    "n(e−) = Q / F",
    "From Cu2+ + 2e− → Cu, n(Cu) = n(e−)/2",
    "m = n × Ar"
  ],
  "line_refs": [
    "L51",
    "L52",
    "L19",
    "L24"
  ],
  "checks": [
    "If time or current were doubled, the mass would double (mass ∝ charge), consistent with Faraday’s laws.",
    "Computed moles of Cu (~0.014 mol) corresponds to under 1 g (since 0.014×63.55 ≈ 0.89), which matches the final result."
  ]
}

value.summary: All six JSON outputs are consistent with the provided report data and equations, with no fabricated quantitative claims. Calculations for dilution (P01), purity/stoichiometry (P02), titration stoichiometry and concentration (P03), bond-enthalpy estimate (P04), electrolysis via Faraday’s law (P05), and equilibrium constant Kc from concentrations (P06) are numerically correct and appropriately caveated where relevant (e.g., mean bond energies are estimates; Kc reported unitless).
